access.description: The registered URL https://www.oracle.com/health/regulatory/certified-health-it/ returns a 301 redirect to https://www.oracle.com/health/certified-health-it/ (the '/regulatory/' path component was dropped). The final page is a static HTML compliance hub with a left sidebar navigation. The EHI Export section is accessible via sidebar link '#ehi-export-lnk'. The actual download links are inside a collapsed accordion labeled 'Read more about EHI Export' (button id: accordion2). The accordion content is present in the HTML source even when collapsed, so curl/grep can find the links without JavaScript. However, a user navigating in a browser must click to expand the accordion. No anti-bot protection encountered — Oracle serves the page fine with a standard User-Agent header. All 6 EHI documentation files downloaded successfully on first attempt.

product_context.description: Oracle Health (formerly Cerner Corporation, acquired by Oracle in 2022) operates one of the largest EHR platforms in the world. The Millennium platform is a comprehensive enterprise health information system used by large hospital systems, academic medical centers, and community hospitals globally. The certified modules (Clinical, CQMs, Health Care Surveys, Immunizations, Patient Portal, PowerChart Touch) are components of the much broader Millennium platform, which includes full revenue cycle management (registration through collections), appointment scheduling, clinical documentation (PowerChart), pharmacy (PharmNet), lab (PathNet), radiology (RadNet), surgery (SurgiNet), nursing, oncology, behavioral health, women's health, rehabilitation, clinical trials, document imaging, multimedia storage, and more. The EHI export documentation explicitly covers the full Millennium database, not just the certified module scope, which is the correct approach under b(10). Additionally, Oracle Health Data Intelligence (HDI) is a separate cloud-based analytics platform that aggregates Millennium data into a longitudinal record; it has its own EHI export pathway via REST APIs.

export_approach.description: Oracle Health takes a native database export approach — the gold standard for EHI completeness. The Millennium platform export dumps the actual production database in SQL format (DDL schemas + INSERT statements), which can be loaded into either a MySQL or Oracle Database instance. For single-tenant (standalone) systems, the population export delivers a full copy of the Millennium database on a customer-supplied encrypted device. For multi-tenant (CommunityWorks/ASP) systems, the data is delivered via SQL files. The export covers four independent data storage locations: (1) Core Millennium EHR database (6,587 tables across 242+ domain categories), (2) Oracle Health Multimedia Storage (DICOM images in tar.gz with XML/JSON metadata, non-DICOM files in CSV-indexed archives), (3) Oracle Health Document Imaging (content management database with its own schema), and (4) Longitudinal Plan/One Plan data (JSON files via HealtheIntent). Additionally, Oracle Health Data Intelligence (HDI) provides a separate export pathway via REST APIs (Bulk Extract + Data Syndication) that delivers the HDI Longitudinal Record as JSON in tar.gz format with ~219 Avro-schema entity types. The single patient export produces ZIP files; the population export may use encrypted physical media for the database component.

documentation_quality.description: The documentation is exceptionally detailed and well-organized. The core Millennium data model reports contain 1,448 HTML pages documenting 6,587 database tables across 242 domain categories. Each table includes a description, definition, table type (ACTIVITY/REFERENCE), and detailed column information with column name, data type, nullability, and a narrative definition. Foreign key relationships between tables are documented. The data model is versioned (2025.4.01, last updated January 16, 2025). The model is provided in both MySQL and Oracle Database variants. The overview PDFs provide clear instructions for consuming the export data, including SQL queries for cross-referencing multimedia files with the core EHR database. The HDI documentation provides Avro-schema entity type definitions with field names, types, and descriptions for approximately 219 entity types. The Document Imaging schema PDF documents the content management database tables with column-level detail. The only minor gap is that value sets/code sets are not fully enumerated in the documentation — the CODE_VALUE and CODE_SET tables serve as the internal code system, but the allowed values aren't pre-documented. Sample data is provided only for the DICOM XML structure.

ehi_coverage.overall_assessment: Oracle Health's EHI export is one of the most comprehensive in the industry, reflecting the depth of the Millennium platform. By exporting the actual production database (6,587 tables across 242 domain categories), the export inherently covers virtually all data the system stores. The export explicitly covers four data storage locations (core EHR database, multimedia storage, document imaging, and longitudinal plan data), leaving very little room for gaps. Clinical data is extensively covered across dozens of domain categories. Billing and revenue cycle data is deeply represented through the PFT (Patient Financial Transactions) suite with 145+ tables covering charges, claims, billing, posting, and account management. Insurance/authorization data is well-documented with dedicated health plan, benefit, and authorization tables. Scheduling has 191+ tables. Document imaging and multimedia storage have dedicated export pathways with their own schemas. The message center and messaging infrastructure tables are present, covering internal messaging. Audit tables (66 audit-related tables) are included. The only area where coverage is less clear is patient portal secure messaging — while portal invitation tables exist (PERSON_PORTAL_INVITE) and the messaging infrastructure is present (MSVC_MESSAGING domain with distribution lists, subscriptions, messaging audit), the traditional 'inbox message' between patient and provider via the portal is likely stored in these messaging tables but the mapping isn't immediately obvious from table names alone. Given the database-native approach, if the data is stored in Millennium, it's in the export.

clinical.evidence: Extensive clinical coverage across dozens of domain categories: clinical_events (CE_ tables with 47+ tables), charting, clinical_reporting, clinical_trials, medication_administration, pharmnet, pharmnet_ambulatory, orders, problem, social_history, fhx_family_history, immunizations, oncology, behavioral_health, womens_health, radnet (radiology), pathnet (lab), micro (microbiology), surginet (surgery/anesthesia), nursing___charting, physician_documentation, dynamic_documentation, structured_clinical, vital signs, and many more. The clinical_events table alone stores all discrete clinical results.

secure_messages.evidence: Message center domain with 11 tables (EMAIL_INFO, MSG_DOC_FAVORITES, MSG_FYI_ASSIGNMENT, MSG_FYI_FILTER, MSG_LETTER_TEMPLATE, TASK_ACTIVITY_ASSIGN_MSG_H, TASK_INTENDED_RECIPIENT, TASK_PUBLISH_QUEUE, TASK_SUBACTIVITY). MSVC_MESSAGING domain with 13 tables (DIST_LIST, MESSAGING_AUDIT, MESSAGING_FAVORITES, MESSAGING_NOTIFY, SUBSCRIPTION, etc.). SI_DIRECT_MESSAGE table for Direct messaging audit. SI_MESSAGE for inbound messages. INVTN_COMMUNICATION table. Community domain contains portal-related infrastructure. The messaging tables may store patient-provider portal messages through the task/messaging infrastructure rather than in dedicated 'inbox' tables.

billing_financial.evidence: Deeply comprehensive billing coverage. PFT (Patient Financial Transactions) suite with 145+ tables across three domains: pft_account_management (25+ pages of tables including PFT_ACCT_FIN_ENCNTR, PFT_BALANCE, PFT_CHARGE, PFT_LINE_ITEM, PFT_LINE_ITEM_DETAIL), pft_billing (75+ tables including BILL_REC, CLAIM_FLD_POSITION, CLAIM_TRANS_INFO, PFT_BILL, PFT_BR_CLAIM_DETAIL, PFT_CHARGE), pft_posting_and_transactions (20+ tables including BATCH_TRANS, FIN_TRANS_GROUP, GL_TRANS_LOG, INTERFACE_TRANSACTION). Also: charge_services domain (11 pages), collections domain (8 pages), revenue_cycle_config, revenue_cycle_core, financial_clearance, encounter___revenue domain. Individual tables include CHARGE, CHARGE_BATCH, CHARGE_EVENT, INVOICE, INVOICE_LINE_ITEM, GS_MED_CLAIM, and many more. Total of ~299 billing/financial-related tables.

insurance_coverage.evidence: Comprehensive insurance coverage. health_plan domain with 18 tables (HEALTH_PLAN, HEALTH_PLAN_ALIAS, HEALTH_PLAN_INFO, NETWORK, ORG_NTWK_PRVDR, PLAN_CONTACT, PLAN_PLAN_RELTN, PROVIDER_ENROLLMENT). benefits domain with 7 tables (BENEFIT, BENEFIT_DETAIL, EEM_BENEFIT, etc.). authorization domain with 20 tables (AUTHORIZATION, AUTHORIZATION_HIST, AUTHORIZATION_ITEM, AUTH_DETAIL, AUTH_REFERRAL_RELTN, etc.). ENCNTR_PLAN tables (14 tables including ENCNTR_PLAN_ELIGIBILITY, ENCNTR_PLAN_ELIG_BENEFIT, ENCNTR_PLAN_COB). PERSON_PLAN tables (8 tables including PERSON_PLAN_PROFILE, PERSON_PLAN_RELTN). referral domain with 12 tables. enterprise_eligibility domain. electronic_prior_authorization domain.

appointments_scheduling.evidence: Extensive scheduling coverage with 191+ tables in the scheduling/scheduling_build/scheduling_orders_integration domains. Key tables include SCH_APPT, SCH_APPT_ACTION, SCH_APPT_BOOK, SCH_EVENT, SCH_RESOURCE, SCH_SLOT, plus scheduling build tables for templates, blocks, and rules. Also patient_tracking domain for real-time location tracking, and encounter domain with 692+ encounter-related tables.

documents_images.evidence: Three dedicated storage systems for documents and images: (1) Oracle Health Multimedia Storage exports DICOM images as .dcm files organized by study UID in tar.gz archives, with XML/JSON metadata documenting person, study, series, and instance-level DICOM attributes. Non-DICOM multimedia (audio, video, photos, PDFs, text files) exported in native format with CSV index files. (2) Oracle Health Document Imaging has its own database schema (Content Management Database Schema PDF documenting AE_ADEFS, AE_APPS, and many more tables) with XSD for annotation data. (3) Core EHR database contains BLOB tables (CE_BLOB, CE_BLOB_RESULT, CE_BLOB_SUMMARY, BLOB_REFERENCE, AP_IMAGE_ tables) and the imaging_document domain. Scanned documents, faxes, patient-uploaded photos — all covered.

audit_trails.evidence: 66 audit-related tables found across the database including: AUDIT_EVENT (definitions of all possible audit events with active/inactive tracking), AUDIT_NAME_DEF, AUDIT_TYPE_DEF, AUDIT_REQUEST, CE_AUDIT_LOG (clinical event audit), PP_AUDIT_EVENT (patient portal audit), CHART_REQUEST_AUDIT, CODING_AUDIT, DISPENSE_REPLACE_AUDIT, IMMUNIZATION_AUDIT, MED_HISTORY_AUDIT, MESSAGING_AUDIT, EPRESCRIBE_AUDIT, TRACKING_AUDIT, VISITCODING_AUDIT, SI_AUDIT, and many domain-specific audit tables (ALERT_AUDIT_*, RX_*_AUDIT, PERSON_HLA_*_AUDIT). Also has the prologue domain (historical OMF_ tables for operational reporting). The AUDIT_EVENT table explicitly notes 'Indicates whether the audit event is being actively audited' suggesting configurable audit scope.

issues: The registered URL redirects from /health/regulatory/certified-health-it/ to /health/certified-health-it/, so the CHPL-registered URL is technically outdated (301 redirect works, but the canonical URL has changed).
Several documentation files still use 'Cerner Corporation' naming despite the Oracle Health rebranding, which could cause confusion about whether the documentation is current.

The patient population export for single-tenant systems requires a 'customer-supplied secure encrypted device' for physical delivery of the full database — this adds logistical complexity and cost to the export process.
The HDI export requires API authentication (bearer token or OAuth 1.0a) and pre-enablement by Oracle Health, meaning it is not fully self-service without initial vendor coordination.
Value sets and code tables (CODE_VALUE, CODE_SET) are not pre-documented in the data model reports — consumers must query the exported database to understand coded values, which adds complexity.

The export documentation references external HealtheIntent API documentation (docs.healtheintent.com) for Longitudinal Plan data format specifications rather than including the schemas inline, creating a dependency on an external documentation source.
The nested ZIP structure (ZIP containing ZIPs) adds friction to accessing the data model documentation.

downloaded_files.description: Single patient EHI export user instructions — describes export artifacts, directory structure, data sources (Core Millennium EHR, Multimedia Storage, DICOM, Document Imaging, Longitudinal Plan), SQL import instructions, and cross-reference queries.

Single patient EHI export data format specifications. Contains nested 'EHI MYSQL DATA MODEL 2025401.zip' with 1,448 HTML pages documenting 6,587 database tables across 242 domain categories, plus 'Longitudinal Plan EHI Export - Single Patient.pdf'.

Patient population EHI export user instructions (23 pages). Covers multi-tenant vs single-tenant delivery, Core Millennium EHR Data, Multimedia Storage (DICOM and non-DICOM), Document Imaging, and Longitudinal Plan data. Includes appendices with DICOM data structure definitions, non-DICOM column definitions, and Document Imaging Content Management Database Schema.

Patient population EHI export data format specifications. Contains: MySQL data model ZIP (6,587 tables), Oracle Database data model ZIP (6,587 tables), Longitudinal Plan PDF, Document Imaging AxAnnotations XSD, Document Imaging Content Management Database Schema PDF, Multimedia Storage DICOM Data Structure and Definitions PDF, Multimedia Storage Non-DICOM Data Column Definitions PDF.

Oracle Health Data Intelligence (HDI) EHI export user instructions (3 pages). Covers REST API authentication, requesting exports via Longitudinal Record Bulk Extract API, and downloading results via Data Syndication API. Export delivered as JSON in tar.gz format.

Oracle Health Data Intelligence EHI export format specifications (196 pages). Documents approximately 219 Avro-schema entity types for the HDI Longitudinal Record ('Poprecord Entity Types'), including clinical data, claims (238 occurrences), billing, charges, payments, appointments, insurance/coverage, documents, and more. Each entity type includes field name, type, and description.

summary: Oracle Health provides one of the most comprehensive EHI export implementations in the industry. The Millennium platform export dumps the entire production database (6,587 tables across 242 domain categories) in SQL format loadable into MySQL or Oracle Database, plus dedicated export pathways for multimedia storage (DICOM and non-DICOM), document imaging, and longitudinal plan data. This native database approach inherently covers clinical, billing/revenue cycle (145+ PFT tables), insurance/authorization, scheduling (191+ tables), document management, messaging, and audit trails (66+ audit tables). The documentation is exceptionally detailed with field-level definitions, data types, nullability, and foreign key relationships for every table. The only notable concerns are logistical: population exports for single-tenant systems require physical encrypted media, the HDI export requires API pre-enablement, and code value sets must be self-discovered from the exported data rather than pre-documented.
notes: Oracle Health also provides a separate EHI export pathway for their Health Data Intelligence (HDI) cloud analytics platform, with its own documentation covering ~219 Avro-schema entity types exported as JSON. The HDI Longitudinal Record represents an aggregated view of patient data and covers claims, billing, appointments, insurance, and clinical data — but notably does not include messaging or audit trail entities (zero occurrences of 'message', 'inbox', 'portal', or 'audit' in the HDI specs). The Millennium database export is far more comprehensive than the HDI export. The data model version 2025.4.01 is very recent, suggesting active maintenance. The domain category listing (242 categories) reads like a comprehensive inventory of a modern enterprise health system: from 'ambulatory_care' to 'workforce', with deep coverage of specialty areas (oncology, behavioral_health, womens_health, rehabilitation, clinical_trials, blood_bank, hla). The SCM (Supply Chain Management) tables (scm_accounting, scm_contract, scm_item, scm_purchasing, scm_requisition, scm_transaction) suggest the export even covers supply chain/materials management data, which goes beyond what most vendors include.
